OLD TAY HO - HISTORICAL MAP
Old Tay Ho brings together historical images, maps, and even documents to show how the area has evolved, which can stimulate a vibrant appreciation of the region, and evoke interest and communications among national and international communities.

Hanoi celebrated its 1000 year founding founding anniversary in 2010. We hope the Old Tay Ho platform can accompany you on a digital, mental, and physical journey, whether with the help of desktop or mobile, to help discover and document this special area of the city.

As you stroll the environs of Ho Tay, stop off for a sip of good Vietnamese coffee, and leaf through one of a number of good history books, travel guides, or your smartphone to get a sense of the city's evolution. And if you find a new gem - picture, map, or document, please contribute to the community!

Historical Images:
Presents photos to show specific places and structures in the area looked like.
Historical Maps:
View current Tay Ho maps overlaid on historical maps and even aerial images.
Historical Documents:
View key relevent historical documents and declarations.

The past two centuries of Hanoi's history were characterized by the colonization of the French after 1858, as well as waves of external wars and threats. Ho Chi Minh declared Vietnamese independence in Hanoi in Sept 1945, but the French returned to occupy the city between 1947-1954. During the American War, Hanoi was repeatedly bombed between 1966 and 1972. In 1976, Hanoi became the capital of unified Vietnam.

Hanoi's, along with Vietnam's wider history, can be grouped into four major periods: pre-French colonial, French colonial (1858-1945), the Warring era (1945–76), Unified era (1976-1986), and the Renovated era (1986–present).

Here are a few existing building highlights from each era. But explore further to find your favorities, including as they have given way to new structures and uses.

FRENCH COLONIAL ERA
(1858 - 1945)
French colonial: The French took control of Hanoi in 1858, Tay Ho was still largely rural with small outlying village settlements. Historic building from that period include Chu Van An School.

Established by French authorities in 1908 as High School of the Protectorate (French: Lycée du Protectorat), this is one of the oldest institutions for secondary education in Indochina. The initial purpose of the French government for this school which was training native civil servant to serve in their colonial establishments. Before 1945, Vietnamese also refered to it was as Pomelo School (Bưởi school), because the school was built on the land of Thuy Khuê village (in the Hậu Lê era, it was the place where the palace Thụy Chương was built at the Kẻ Bưởi area, beside the West Lake (Hanoi), . In 1945 it was renamed Chu Van An high school - named after the famous teacher in the history of Viet Nam.

READ MORE
WARRING ERA
(1945 - 1976)
Following the end of WWII in 1945, the French returned to Hanoi in 1947-54. The North Westlake Bunker was built by the French, but apparently also used by the Vietnamese in the American War to defend Hanoi.

Perched on an incline at the upper end of the lake on Ngoc Van Street, a 1950s French military blockhouse stands guard. The fortification was likely built by the French during the Indochine War to protect the Red River Delta and Hanoi from attacks by the Viet Minh to the south and China to the north. The blockhouse was also likely re-used as a military installation after the French left. It is said to have been used as an anti-aircraft post during the ‘American war'. You can get a closer look at the “Block House” after 4pm when it opens as an informal café, serving fresh up juices, beer, smoothies, and one of the best views across Tay Ho lake. Or, go along and have your hair cut by Mr Nam who operates his hair dressing salon out of the base of its fortifications.

UNIFIED ERA
(1976 - 1986)
To be updated

READ MORE
RENOVATED ERA
(1986- Now)
The Đổi Mới ("Renovation") economic reforms initiated in Vietnam in 1986 gave rise to growing rates of prosperity, but also rapid urban change and expansion. During due its proximity to the center of Hanoi, but relative spaciousness, the area became quite popular with foreigners.

Thang Loi (Victory) hotel emerged as one of the early resort hotels on the lake in the 1980s, built in 1973 with assistance from the Cuban government, further tourist landmarks such as the Intercon Hotel was opened in 2007.

Thang Loi Hotel is a four-star international standard hotel with 175 rooms, located on Yen Phu Street. This hotel was put into operation in mid-1975 as a present from Cuban people, and built with.Cuban engineers and workers travelled to Vietnam/ The Thang Loi hotel has special architecture and preserves space and architectural values of history, culture, and landscape. Based on the Hanoi planning on tourism development to 2020, orientation to 2030 that has been approved, Hanoi people’s committee said that the renovation and upgrading of Thang Loi hotel are necessary, creating a highlight for the West Lake area and Hanoi tourism.
